body_html:
Probably no.
How come the shapes of h^(t-1) and h^(t) are different! If these two vectors are of different shape, you can't even maintain the RNN loop!

Suppose at a certain time step t0, the size of hidden state changed from [m] (the size of h^(t0-1)) to [n] (the size of h^(t0)), how can you run the RNN loop for time step t0+1? The matrix multiplication W^(gh)h^(t0) will cause a mismatch.

Try to write the code and you'll find it out.

Probably no.
How come the shapes of h^(t-1) and h^(t) are different! If these two vectors are of different shape, you can't even maintain the RNN loop!
Suppose at a certain time step t0, the size of hidden state changed from [m] (the size of h^(t0-1)) to [n] (the size of h^(t0)), how can you run the RNN loop for time step t0+1? The matrix multiplication W^(gh)h^(t0) will cause a mismatch.
Try to write the code and you'll find it out.
body:
Probably no.
How come the shapes of h^(t-1) and h^(t) are different! If these two vectors are of different shape, you can't even maintain the RNN loop!

Suppose at a certain time step `t0`, the size of hidden state changed from [m] (the size of h^(t0-1)) to [n] (the size of h^(t0)), how can you run the RNN loop for time step t0+1? The matrix multiplication W^(gh)h^(t0) will cause a mismatch.

Try to write the code and you'll find it out.
